Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) for FY 2013 in Korea
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Forest Hoyt Andrews of Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis to conduct a research project in Biology during the summer of 2013 at Seoul National University in Seoul, South Korea. The project title is "Exploring the Diversity of the Oxidative Folding Pathway via X-ray Crystallography." The host scientist is Professor Se Won Suh.

Oxidative folding is the process of introducing disulfide bonds into proteins. In most bacteria this pathway is essentially composed of two enzymes that form a complex. However the way in which these two enzymes have evolved to interact with one another is not quite as conserved as originally thought. This project performs cocrystallization experiments on these various oxidative folding enzyme partners in an attempt to identify novel interactions.

Broader impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce. In addition to the planned research, the Fellow will visit local high schools and observe how teaching science is approached in Korea and compare it to his experience teaching high school science in the US. Upon returning the Fellow will hold an open seminar describing the cultural differences and educational approaches in teaching science between the United States and Korea.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The East Asia Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) fellowship provided me with the opportunity to carry out X-ray crystallography research at the world-renowned Seoul National University (SNU) under the guidance of Professor Se Won Suh. During my short time at SNU, I received training on several different protein purification systems, X-ray crystallography software packages, and the mosquito robot used for high-throughput screening of protein crystallization conditions. All of this training enabled me to successfully purify, crystallize, and determine the structure of an enzyme isolated from the organism Mycobacterium smegmatis in less than eight weeks. A manuscript describing these findings is currently under preparation in which lab members from both my home institution (Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis; IUPUI) and my host institution (SNU) will share authorship.

During my time at SNU, I was introduced to many incredibly bright and driven Korean colleagues whom undoubtedly will be great scientists and hopefully future collaborators. This early career international research experience has not only been proven beneficial for myself, but also for a few younger scientists in my home lab. Several undergraduate students at IUPUI have worked on this project and subsequently will share authorship of the manuscript. These undergraduate students have all applied for graduate research programs, and intend on pursuing careers in the sciences. By witnessing my participation in the EAPSI program, they have become keenly aware at a very young age that science is truly an international discipline.
